entry.title: FlashAttention(3): Online Softmax
entry.content:
Motivation: In FlashAttention, we process attention scores in blocks. We cannot see all values at once, yet we need to compute the correct softmax.

Goal: Compute softmax by processing values sequentially in chunks, maintaining running statistics.

Example: Computing Softmax for One Attention Row

Given: Attention scores S=[3,1,5,2,4,6]S = [3, 1, 5, 2, 4, 6]S=[3,1,5,2,4,6]﻿

Standard safe softmax (requires all values):

  1. Find global max: m=6m = 6m=6﻿
  1. Compute:e3−6+e1−6+e5−6+e2−6+e4−6+e6−6∑=e−3+e−5+e−1+e−4+e−2+e0∑\frac{e^{3-6} + e^{1-6} + e^{5-6} + e^{2-6} + e^{4-6} + e^{6-6}}{\sum} = \frac{e^{-3} + e^{-5} + e^{-1} + e^{-4} + e^{-2} + e^{0}}{\sum}∑e3−6+e1−6+e5−6+e2−6+e4−6+e6−6​=∑e−3+e−5+e−1+e−4+e−2+e0​﻿

But we can't do this in FlashAttention because we only see small blocks at a time!

Online Softmax (processes in chunks)

Split into chunks: S1=[3,1]S_1 = [3, 1]S1​=[3,1]﻿, S2=[5,2]S_2 = [5, 2]S2​=[5,2]﻿, S3=[4,6]S_3 = [4, 6]S3​=[4,6]﻿

Process chunk by chunk:

Chunk 1: S1=[3,1]S_1 = [3, 1]S1​=[3,1]﻿

  • Local max: m1=3m_1 = 3m1​=3﻿
  • Local sum: ℓ1=e3−3+e1−3=e0+e−2=1+0.135=1.135\ell_1 = e^{3-3} + e^{1-3} = e^0 + e^{-2} = 1 + 0.135 = 1.135ℓ1​=e3−3+e1−3=e0+e−2=1+0.135=1.135﻿

Chunk 2: S2=[5,2]S_2 = [5, 2]S2​=[5,2]﻿

  • Local max: m~2=5\tilde{m}_2 = 5m~2​=5﻿
  • Update global max: m2=max⁡(m1,m~2)=max⁡(3,5)=5m_2 = \max(m_1, \tilde{m}_2) = \max(3, 5) = 5m2​=max(m1​,m~2​)=max(3,5)=5﻿
  • Problem: Our previous sum ℓ1\ell_1ℓ1​﻿ was computed with base m1=3m_1 = 3m1​=3﻿, but now the base changed to m2=5m_2 = 5m2​=5﻿!
  • Rescale previous sum: ℓ1′=ℓ1⋅em1−m2=1.135⋅e3−5=1.135⋅e−2=0.154\ell_1' = \ell_1 \cdot e^{m_1 - m_2} = 1.135 \cdot e^{3-5} = 1.135 \cdot e^{-2} = 0.154ℓ1′​=ℓ1​⋅em1​−m2​=1.135⋅e3−5=1.135⋅e−2=0.154﻿
  • Add new contribution: ℓ2=ℓ1′+(e5−5+e2−5)=0.154+e0+e−3=0.154+1+0.050=1.204\ell_2 = \ell_1' + (e^{5-5} + e^{2-5}) = 0.154 + e^0 + e^{-3} = 0.154 + 1 + 0.050 = 1.204ℓ2​=ℓ1′​+(e5−5+e2−5)=0.154+e0+e−3=0.154+1+0.050=1.204﻿

Chunk 3: S3=[4,6]S_3 = [4, 6]S3​=[4,6]﻿

  • Local max: m~3=6\tilde{m}_3 = 6m~3​=6﻿
  • Update global max: m3=max⁡(m2,m~3)=max⁡(5,6)=6m_3 = \max(m_2, \tilde{m}_3) = \max(5, 6) = 6m3​=max(m2​,m~3​)=max(5,6)=6﻿
  • Rescale previous sum: ℓ2′=ℓ2⋅em2−m3=1.204⋅e5−6=1.204⋅e−1=0.443\ell_2' = \ell_2 \cdot e^{m_2 - m_3} = 1.204 \cdot e^{5-6} = 1.204 \cdot e^{-1} = 0.443ℓ2′​=ℓ2​⋅em2​−m3​=1.204⋅e5−6=1.204⋅e−1=0.443﻿
  • Add new contribution: ℓ3=ℓ2′+(e4−6+e6−6)=0.443+e−2+e0=0.443+0.135+1=1.578\ell_3 = \ell_2' + (e^{4-6} + e^{6-6}) = 0.443 + e^{-2} + e^0 = 0.443 + 0.135 + 1 = 1.578ℓ3​=ℓ2′​+(e4−6+e6−6)=0.443+e−2+e0=0.443+0.135+1=1.578﻿

Final result:

  • Global max: m=6m = 6m=6﻿ (same as standard)
  • Global sum: ℓ=1.578\ell = 1.578ℓ=1.578﻿ (same as standard: e−3+e−5+e−1+e−4+e−2+e0=1.578e^{-3} + e^{-5} + e^{-1} + e^{-4} + e^{-2} + e^{0} = 1.578e−3+e−5+e−1+e−4+e−2+e0=1.578﻿)

The Key Insight: Rescaling

When we see a new, larger max mnew>moldm_{\text{new}} > m_{\text{old}}mnew​>mold​﻿:

Our previous sum ℓold\ell_{\text{old}}ℓold​﻿ was computed relative to base moldm_{\text{old}}mold​﻿:

To change the base to mnewm_{\text{new}}mnew​﻿, we multiply by the correction factor:

Mathematical equivalence:

This is exactly the same as if we had computed everything with mnewm_{\text{new}}mnew​﻿ from the start!

Summary

Online softmax achieves the same result as safe softmax because:

  1. Both use the global maximum to prevent overflow/underflow
  1. Rescaling maintains correctness: When the max changes, we adjust previous sums using emold−mnewe^{m_{\text{old}} - m_{\text{new}}}emold​−mnew​﻿
  1. Final result is identical: After processing all chunks, we have the same mmm﻿ and ∑exj−m\sum e^{x_j - m}∑exj​−m﻿ as standard safe softmax

The difference:

  • Safe softmax: See all values → compute
  • Online softmax: See chunks → update running max and sum → same final result.

entry.title: FlashAttention(4): all-together: tiling&fusing
entry.content:
FlashAttention asks: "Can we calculate the final output without ever writing the giant N×NN \times NN×N﻿ matrix to HBM?"

The Strategy: Tiling.
We break the Query, Key, and Value matrices into small blocks that fit entirely inside the tiny SRAM.

The Algorithm:

  1. Load Block Q1,K1,V1Q_1, K_1, V_1Q1​,K1​,V1​﻿ into SRAM.
  1. Compute S1,1=Q1K1TS_{1,1} = Q_1 K_1^TS1,1​=Q1​K1T​﻿ in SRAM.
  1. Compute Softmax locally in SRAM.
  1. Multiply by V1V_1V1​﻿ immediately in SRAM.
  1. Accumulate the result into the output buffer.
  1. Repeat for next blocks.

The Result:
The massive N×NN \times NN×N﻿ attention matrix is never fully materialized in HBM. It is created piecemeal in SRAM, used immediately, and discarded.

  • Memory IO: Reduced by 8x to 10x.
  • Speed: Faster, because we are no longer memory-bound.

FlashAttention (Forward Pass)

Here is the brief mathematical workflow for FlashAttention (Forward Pass).

The key distinction is that we process the matrices in Tiles (Blocks) to stay inside the SRAM (fast memory), updating the output iteratively using Online Softmax.

  1. Tiling (The Setup)

    We split the input matrices (Q,K,VQ, K, VQ,K,V﻿) living in HBM (Slow Memory) into blocks of size BBB﻿ by row:

    • QQQ﻿ is split into row blocks: Q1,Q2,…Q_1, Q_2, \dotsQ1​,Q2​,…﻿
    • K,VK, VK,V﻿ are split into row blocks: (K1,V1),(K2,V2),…(K_1, V_1), (K_2, V_2), \dots(K1​,V1​),(K2​,V2​),…﻿
  1. Outer Loop (Load Query)

    For each block of Queries QiQ_iQi​﻿:

    1. Load QiQ_iQi​﻿ from HBM →\to→﻿ SRAM.
    1. Initialize running stats in SRAM:
      • Oi=0O_i = 0Oi​=0﻿ (Un-normalized Output)
      • ℓi=0\ell_i = 0ℓi​=0﻿ (Running Sum)
      • mi=−∞m_i = -\inftymi​=−∞﻿ (Running Max)
  1. Inner Loop (Scan Keys/Values)

    We iterate through every block jjj﻿ of Keys/Values:

    1. Load Kj,VjK_j, V_jKj​,Vj​﻿ from HBM →\to→﻿ SRAM.
    1. Compute Scores (On Chip):
      Sij=Qi⋅KjT S_{ij} = Q_i \cdot K_j^T Sij​=Qi​⋅KjT​﻿
    1. Update Statistics (Online Softmax):
      • Find local max of current block: m~=rowmax(Sij)\tilde{m} = \text{rowmax}(S_{ij})m~=rowmax(Sij​)﻿
      • Find new global max: mnew=max⁡(mi,m~)m_{new} = \max(m_i, \tilde{m})mnew​=max(mi​,m~)﻿
      • Compute Un-normalized Probs: Pij=eSij−mnewP_{ij} = e^{S_{ij} - m_{new}}Pij​=eSij​−mnew​﻿
      • Update Global Sum:
        ℓnew=(ℓi⋅emi−mnew)+rowsum(Pij) \ell_{new} = (\ell_i \cdot e^{m_i - m_{new}}) + \text{rowsum}(P_{ij}) ℓnew​=(ℓi​⋅emi​−mnew​)+rowsum(Pij​)﻿
    1. Update Output (Rescale & Add):
      Onew=(Oi⋅emi−mnew)+(Pij⋅Vj) O_{new} = (O_i \cdot e^{m_i - m_{new}}) + (P_{ij} \cdot V_j) Onew​=(Oi​⋅emi​−mnew​)+(Pij​⋅Vj​)﻿
    1. Write State: mi←mnew,ℓi←ℓnew,Oi←Onewm_i \leftarrow m_{new}, \ell_i \leftarrow \ell_{new}, O_i \leftarrow O_{new}mi​←mnew​,ℓi​←ℓnew​,Oi​←Onew​﻿
    1. Discard: Delete Sij,Kj,VjS_{ij}, K_j, V_jSij​,Kj​,Vj​﻿ from SRAM immediately.
  1. Finalization (Write Back)

    After the inner loop finishes (all K,VK, VK,V﻿ blocks processed for this QiQ_iQi​﻿):

    1. Normalize:
    1. Save: Write OfinalO_{final}Ofinal​﻿ from SRAM →\to→﻿ HBM.

The Backward Pass (Re-computation)

Standard Attention saves the huge N×NN \times NN×N﻿ attention map during the forward pass so it can be used for the backward pass (Gradient calculation). This eats massive VRAM.

FlashAttention does not save it.

Backward Pass:

  • It grabs Q,K,VQ, K, VQ,K,V﻿ again.
  • It re-calculates the attention scores on the fly using the Tiling method.
  • It calculates the gradient.

Why is this faster?
Because re-doing the math (FLOPS) is actually faster than reading the terabyte matrix from HBM.

  • Compute = Cheap.
  • Memory Bandwidth = Expensive.

Torch Implementation of FlashAttention(forward Pass)

pedagogical version

In the code below, we loop through blocks of query and key/value to calculate the attention matrix for each block. Then incrementally calculate the final output matrix OOO﻿.

Note:

Theoretically the loop through query should be parallelled.

def flash_attention_v2_forward(Q, K, V, causal=False, block_size=64):
    """
    Flash Attention v2 - even more optimized
    Key improvement: Better work partitioning across blocks
    
    This version processes blocks more efficiently by:
    1. Reducing redundant computations
    2. Better memory access patterns
    """
    B, H, N, d = Q.shape
    
    O = torch.zeros_like(Q)
    scale = 1.0 / math.sqrt(d)
    
    num_blocks = math.ceil(N / block_size)
    
    # Process each query block
    for i in range(num_blocks):
        q_start = i * block_size
        q_end = min((i + 1) * block_size, N)
        Q_block = Q[:, :, q_start:q_end, :]
        
        # Online softmax accumulators
        m_i = torch.full((B, H, q_end - q_start, 1), float('-inf'), device=Q.device)
        l_i = torch.zeros(B, H, q_end - q_start, 1, device=Q.device)
        O_i = torch.zeros_like(Q_block)
        
        # Determine which K/V blocks to attend to
        max_j = i + 1 if causal else num_blocks
        
        for j in range(max_j):
            k_start = j * block_size
            k_end = min((j + 1) * block_size, N)
            K_block = K[:, :, k_start:k_end, :]
            V_block = V[:, :, k_start:k_end, :]
            
            # Compute scores
            S_ij = torch.matmul(Q_block, K_block.transpose(-2, -1)) * scale
            
            # Causal masking
            if causal and i == j:
                q_idx = torch.arange(q_start, q_end, device=Q.device)[:, None]
                k_idx = torch.arange(k_start, k_end, device=Q.device)[None, :]
                causal_mask = q_idx < k_idx
                S_ij = S_ij.masked_fill(causal_mask, float('-inf'))
            
            # Online softmax update
            m_ij = S_ij.max(dim=-1, keepdim=True)[0]
            p_ij = torch.exp(S_ij - m_ij)
            l_ij = p_ij.sum(dim=-1, keepdim=True)
            
            # Update global statistics
            m_i_new = torch.maximum(m_i, m_ij)
            l_i_new = torch.exp(m_i - m_i_new) * l_i + torch.exp(m_ij - m_i_new) * l_ij
            
            # Update output
            O_i = torch.exp(m_i - m_i_new) * O_i + \
                  torch.exp(m_ij - m_i_new) * torch.matmul(p_ij, V_block)
            
            m_i = m_i_new
            l_i = l_i_new
        
        # Final normalization
        O_i = O_i / l_i
        O[:, :, q_start:q_end, :] = O_i
    
    return O
    
class FlashAttention(torch.nn.Module):
    """
    Flash Attention module wrapper
    """
    def __init__(self, d_model, num_heads, block_size=64):
        super().__init__()
        assert d_model % num_heads == 0
        
        self.d_model = d_model
        self.num_heads = num_heads
        self.head_dim = d_model // num_heads
        self.block_size = block_size

        self.W_qkv = torch.nn.Linear(d_model, 3 * d_model)
        self.W_o = torch.nn.Linear(d_model, d_model)

    def forward(self, x, causal=False):
        B, L, D = x.shape
        
        # Project to Q, K, V
        qkv = self.W_qkv(x)
        qkv = qkv.reshape(B, L, 3, self.num_heads, self.head_dim)
        qkv = qkv.permute(2, 0, 3, 1, 4)  # (3, B, H, L, d)
        Q, K, V = qkv[0], qkv[1], qkv[2]
        
        # Apply flash attention
        output = flash_attention_v2_forward(Q, K, V, causal=causal, block_size=self.block_size)
        
        # Reshape and project
        output = output.transpose(1, 2).reshape(B, L, D)
        output = self.W_o(output)
        
        return output

Summary: Why it matters

FeatureStandard AttentionFlashAttention
Peak MemoryO(N²)O(N)
HBM I/OO(N²)O(N²/B) ≈ O(N²)
FLOPsO(N²d)O(N²d)
BottleneckMemory BandwidthCompute

Verdict:
FlashAttention turns the "Memory Wall" problem into a "Compute" problem. Since GPUs are getting better at compute faster than they are getting better at memory bandwidth, this is the winning strategy.

Today, FlashAttention-2 (and the new FlashAttention-3) is standard in essentially every major library (PyTorch 2.0+, DeepSpeed, vLLM, HuggingFace). If you run torch.nn.functional.scaled_dot_product_attention, you are likely running FlashAttention under the hood.

This is why techniques like FlashAttention (optimizing memory access), Sliding Window Attention (Mistral), and Linear Attention (Mamba/RNNs) exist—they aim to reduce the N2N^2N2﻿ term to NNN﻿. FlashAttention is the algorithm that effectively "fixed" the Transformer's memory bottleneck for long sequences. If DeepSpeed is about managing weights across GPUs, FlashAttention is about managing data movement inside a single GPU.

It is based on a profound realization: GPUs are fast at math, but slow at memory.

entry.title: LayerNorm vs RMSNorm: What’s different?
entry.content:
What they normalize?

LayerNorm

For a hidden vector x∈Rdx \in \mathbb{R}^dx∈Rd﻿ (one token, one layer), LN does:

So LN outputs zero-mean, unit-variance (per token, across hidden dims), then applies learnable scale γ\gammaγ﻿ and bias β\betaβ﻿.

RMSNorm(Root Mean Square Norm)

Usually there’s no β\betaβ﻿ (bias) term in RMSNorm (though you can add it).

What it implies in practice

Compute / simplicity

  • RMSNorm is cheaper: no mean, no variance of centered values.
  • Fewer ops and sometimes easier to fuse efficiently.

Behavior

  • LN is invariant to adding a constant shift: xx x﻿→\to→﻿ x+cx + c x+c﻿ won’t change the normalized output (before γ\gammaγ﻿,β\betaβ﻿).
  • RMSNorm is not shift-invariant.

Stability / training

  • In modern Transformers (especially pre-norm), RMSNorm often trains just as well and is common in LLMs (e.g., LLaMA-style).
  • LN gives a bit more “strict” normalization (center + scale), which can sometimes help in settings where shifts matter.

When does RMSNorm help (vs LayerNorm)?

What RMSNorm changes

  • LayerNorm centers + scales:
    • subtract mean, divide by std
  • RMSNorm scales only:
    • divide by RMS magnitude (no mean subtraction)

Where RMSNorm helps most

  1. Efficiency / kernel simplicity
    • Fewer reductions/ops than LN → easier to fuse, slightly faster, slightly less overhead.
    • At LLM scale, tiny savings per layer add up.
  1. Works very well with pre-norm + residual
    • In pre-norm, you already have a strong residual pathway; you mostly want the norm to control scale (keep activations in a good range). RMSNorm does exactly that without forcing zero-mean.
  1. Stable behavior with bf16/fp16 pipelines
    • RMSNorm often behaves nicely in mixed precision because it avoids the mean-subtraction step (one less place for cancellation/rounding sensitivity), though this is not a universal “always better” — it’s more like “rarely worse” in common LLM setups.

When LN might be preferable

  • If your model or data causes large mean shifts that hurt training, LN’s centering can help.
  • If you rely on shift-invariance (LN is invariant to adding a constant bias across features; RMSNorm isn’t).

Practical guidance

  • Deep decoder-only LLM (pre-norm): RMSNorm is a very common “good default”.
  • Encoder / older architectures / some fine-tuning regimes: LayerNorm is still totally fine and sometimes better.

entry.title: FlashAttention(1): What it is and why we need it

link.title: FlashAttention(1): What it is and why we need it

entry.content:
Introduction

Attention mechanisms are the foundation of modern Large Language Models, but they come with a critical limitation: quadratic memory complexity. For a sequence of length NNN﻿, standard attention requires O(N2)O(N²)O(N2)﻿ memory to store the attention matrix, creating a hard ceiling on the context lengths LLMs can process.

FlashAttention, introduced by Dao et al. (2022), offers an elegant solution. By carefully orchestrating memory access patterns and leveraging GPU memory hierarchy, it achieves the same mathematical result as standard attention while being 2-4x faster and using 10-20x less memory.

The key insight? For the long sequences (for example N>1024N > 1024N>1024﻿, depending on the hardware constraints) that LLMs require, standard attention becomes memory-bound rather than compute-bound. The bottleneck isn't the number of floating-point operations (FLOPs), but the expensive reads and writes between GPU High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) and on-chip SRAM.

The Hardware Reality: HBM vs. SRAM

To understand FlashAttention, you must understand the anatomy of an NVIDIA GPU (like an A100).

  1. HBM (High Bandwidth Memory):
    • Size: Massive (40GB - 80GB).
    • Speed: ~1.5-2 TB/s (A100), ~3.35 TB/s (H100)
    • Role: The "RAM". Where your weights and KV cache live.
  1. SRAM (Static RAM / On-chip Memory):
    • Size: 192 KB per SM; total 20MB on A100 (108 SMs × 192KB ≈ 20MB)
    • Speed: ~19 TB/s effective bandwidth
    • Role: The "L1 cache" where the CUDA cores actually do math

The Bottleneck:

  • Moving data from HBM to SRAM is expensive.
  • Doing math inside SRAM is cheap.

This is the fundamental constraint that FlashAttention exploits.

FlashAttention asks: "Can we calculate the final output without ever writing the giant N×NN \times NN×N﻿ matrix to HBM?"

The Strategy: Tiling. We break the Query, Key, and Value matrices into small blocks that fit entirely inside the tiny SRAM.

entry.title: Pre-norm vs Post-norm
entry.content:
Let xℓx_\ellxℓ​﻿ be the hidden state entering layer ℓ\ellℓ﻿, and Fℓ(⋅)F_\ell(\cdot)Fℓ​(⋅)﻿ be a sublayer (attention or MLP).

Post-norm (original Transformer style)

Pre-norm (modern LLM default)

Why pre-norm stabilizes very deep models

It gives you a clean “identity gradient highway”

Back-propagation through the residual:

Pre-norm:

That +I+I+I﻿ is the big deal: even if the sublayer path is noisy/unstable early in training, gradients still have a near-identity route across many layers. So deep stacks don’t need every layer to be “well-behaved” from step 1.

Post-norm:

Now the gradient gets multiplicatively gated by the norm Jacobian JNormJ_{\mathrm{Norm}}JNorm​﻿ every layer. Over depth, products of these Jacobians can shrink or distort gradients (and they also couple dimensions). That makes very deep Transformers harder to optimize without careful tricks.

Norm is outside the residual path in pre-norm

In post-norm, the output is always normalized, which sounds nice, but it means the residual “skip” isn’t a true skip anymore — it’s always followed by a normalization transform. In pre-norm, the skip path is literally xℓ→xℓ+1x_\ell \to x_{\ell+1}xℓ​→xℓ+1​﻿ untouched, which improves signal/gradient propagation in deep networks.

Optimization early phase is easier

Empirically, post-norm often needs more delicate LR/warmup/init to avoid divergence as depth grows. Pre-norm is more forgiving, so it became the default for deep decoder-only LLMs.

Rule of thumb: the deeper the model, the more pre-norm tends to “just work”.

entry.title: FlashAttention(2): The native attention and its constraints

link.title: FlashAttention(2): The native attention and its constraints

entry.content:
The "Standard" Attention (The Wasteful Way)

Let's look at the standard calculation:

The fundamental problem with standard attention is that the attention matrix doesn't fit in SRAM (on-chip memory).

For a sequence length of N=4096N=4096N=4096﻿ with FP16:

  • Attention matrix size: 40962×2 bytes=32MB4096^2 × 2 \space bytes = 32 MB40962×2 bytes=32MB﻿
  • SRAM size per SM: 192 KB

Since 32MB>>192KB,32 MB >> 192 KB,32MB>>192KB,﻿ the attention matrix cannot be kept on-chip. Thus it must be stored in HBM.

A naive implementation performs attention in three separate kernel launches, materializing intermediate results in HBM each time:

  1. MatMul (S=QKTS = Q K^TS=QKT﻿):
    • Load Q,KQ, KQ,K﻿ from HBM to SRAM.
    • Compute SSS﻿ (Score Matrix, size N×NN \times NN×N﻿).
    • WRITE SSS﻿ to HBM. (Huge write).
  1. Softmax (P=softmax(S)P = \text{softmax}(S)P=softmax(S)﻿):
    • READ SSS﻿ from HBM.
    • Compute Exponentials/Sum.
    • WRITE PPP﻿ to HBM. (Huge write).
  1. MatMul (O=PVO = P VO=PV﻿):
    • READ PPP﻿ from HBM.
    • Load VVV﻿.
    • Compute Output.
    • Write Output to HBM.

Numerical instability in standard softmax

The "Numerical Instability" of Standard Softmax comes down to the physical limitations of how computers store numbers (Floating Point Arithmetic).

In pure mathematics, e1000e^{1000}e1000﻿ is just a very large number. In a computer (using float32), e1000e^{1000}e1000﻿ is an error.

Here are the two specific ways Standard Softmax crashes your training: Overflow and Underflow.

The Explosion (Overflow) - The Most Common Crash

The standard formula is:

float32 Range: ±1.2×10−38±1.2 \times 10^{-38}±1.2×10−38﻿ to ±3.4×1038±3.4 \times 10^{38}±3.4×1038﻿

  • The Overflow Threshold: e88.7≈3.4×1038e^{88.7} ≈ 3.4 \times 10^{38}e88.7≈3.4×1038﻿ (the maximum)
  • Anything larger becomes inf

The Scenario:
Imagine your attention score (dot product) is 100. (This is common in unscaled attention).

  1. Calculate Numerator: e100e^{100}e100﻿.
  1. Computer says: "That is bigger than 103810^{38}1038﻿. I will call it Infinity (inf)."
  1. Calculate Denominator: Sum of infinities = Infinity.
  1. Result:

entry.title: Bubble Sort
entry.content:
Bubble Sort

Bubble sort is sorting an array by repeatedly swapping the maximum element to the end of the array.

Stability and Complexity

Bubble sort is stable.

Time complexity Space complexity
$O(n^2)$ $O(1)$

Pseudo Code

def bubble_sort(arr):
    for i in range(len(arr)):
        # sort arr[:len(arr)-i+1]
        for j in range(len(arr)-i-1):
            if arr[j+1]>arr[j]:
                arr[j], arr[j+1] = arr[j+1], arr[j]

Improved Bubble Sort

There are two ways to improve the effiency of bubble sort:

1. early stop the swapping

If in an iteration, there is no swapping, we know that the array has already been sorted and there is no need to do the rest iterations.

entry.title: Message Passing Interface
entry.content:
What is MPI

MPI is a standard library for message passing.

Why MPI

  • The MPI interface is designed and implemented with performance in mind.
  • The MPI interface will take advantage of the fastest network transport available to it when sending messages.
    For an instance, to communicate with two different processes within a node, MPI will use a shared memory(within a computer) to send and receive messages rather than network communications. On fast interconnects, within a high performance computer cluster it already knows how to take advantage of transports like Infiniband or Myrinet for communications to processes on other nodes, and if all else fails only it will use the Standard Internet TCP/IP.
  • MPI Enforces other guarantees. Retries, messages arrive in order.
  • MPI is designed for multi-node technical computing. We can spend our time figuring out how to decompose our scientific problem rather than having to worry about network protocols.

Several ways of communication

Broadcast (one to many)

One process has a piece of data and broadcasts it to many or all of the other processes. All other processes will receive the same piece of data.

Scatter (one to many)

A close relative of the broadcast is Scatter, where one process divides values between many others. Different processes may receive different pieces of data.

Gather (many to one)

The inverse of Scatter is Gather. In which many processes have different parts of the overall picture which are then brought together to one process.

Reduction (one to many)

Reduction which combines communication and computation of many useful sorts of operations finding a global minimum, maximum sum or product are fundamentally reduction operations. Consider doing a global sum of data. Each process calculates its partial sum and then these are combined into a global sum on one process.

entry.title: Neural Networks
entry.content:
Neuron

Neural Network

Neural networks is combining multiple neurons together. Below is the structure of a 2-layer neural network:

$a^{[0]}$ is the input layer, $a^{[1]}$ is the hidden layer, and $a^{[2]}$ is the output layer. For layer 1 the activation function is $g$ and for layer 2 the activation function is sigmoid. Parameter $w^{[1]}$ is a $4\times3$ matrix; parameter $b^{[1]}$ is a $4\times1$ vector. For layer 1 we have

\[W^{[1]}=\left[ \begin{matrix} w^{[1]T}_1\\ w^{[1]T}_2\\ w^{[1]T}_3\\ w^{[1]T}_4\\ \end{matrix} \right]\] \[b^{[1]}=\left[ \begin{matrix} b^{[1]}_1\\ b^{[1]}_2\\ b^{[1]}_3\\ b^{[1]}_4\\ \end{matrix} \right]\] \[z^{[1]}_1 = w^{[1]T}_1a^{[0]}+b^{[1]}_1, a^{[1]}_1=g(z^{[1]}_1)\] \[z^{[1]}_2 = w^{[1]T}_2a^{[0]}+b^{[1]}_2, a^{[1]}_2=g(z^{[1]}_2)\] \[z^{[1]}_3 = w^{[1]T}_3a^{[0]}+b^{[1]}_3, a^{[1]}_3=g(z^{[1]}_3)\] \[z^{[1]}_4 = w^{[1]T}_4a^{[0]}+b^{[1]}_4, a^{[1]_4}=g(z^{[1]}_4)\]

Vectorize it we get:

\[z^{[1]}=W^{[1]}a^{[0]}, A^{[1]}=g(Z^{[1]})\]

Similarly for layer 2 we get

\[Z^{[2]}=W^{[2]}A^{[1]}, A^{[2]}=\sigma(z^{[2]})\]

Vectorizing Across Multiple Examples

Forward Propagation

We define the training set $A^{[0]}$ to have m examples, that is

\[A^{[0]} = \left[ \begin{matrix} a^{[0](1)]}, a^{[0](2)]}, \cdots, a^{[0](m)]} \end{matrix} \right]\]

Then we have

\[Z^{[1]}=w^{[1]}A^{[0]}+b^{[1]}, A^{[1]}=g(Z^{[1]})\]

Similarly,

\[Z^{[2]}=w^{[2]}A^{[1]}+b^{[2]}, A^{[2]}=\sigma(Z^{[2]})\]

Cost Function

We define the cost function to be a cross entropy:

\[J(\hat Y, Y) = Y*\log\hat Y+(1-Y)*\log(1-\hat Y)\]

Backward propagation

We know that if we use the sigmoid function for layer 2 and use the cross-entropy as the cost function, the gradient for $Z^{[2]}$ will be:

\[dZ^{[2]}=A^{[2]}-Y\] \[dW^{[2]}=\frac{d\mathcal J}{dZ^{[2]}}\]

entry.title: Convolutional Neural Network
entry.content:
What is a CNN made of

A full convolutional neural network are made of:

  1. input layer
  2. convolutional layer
  3. ReLU layer
  4. pooling layer
  5. fully-connected layer

Why do we need CNN

  1. We need to reserve the spacial information of input;
  2. We need less parameters;
  3. To avoid overfitting caused by large amount of parameters.

2-D convolution

Commonly used techniques

Padding

Stride


Note: A stride of 1 is equivalent to a standard convolution.

Multi-channal convolution

Filter

A filter is actually a collection of kernals in general case. One kernal for one channel. For example: for an image that has 3 channels, a filter has 3 kernals per channel.

Each of the per-channel processed versions are then summed together to form one channel. The kernels of a filter each produce one version of each channel, and the filter as a whole produces one overall output channel.

Finally, then there’s the bias term. The way the bias term works here is that each output filter has one bias term. The bias gets added to the output channel so far to produce the final output channel.

So for each filter, it produces one output channel. outputs for all filters concatenated are the final multi-channeled output.
